text: Our transformation journey started
probably about five years ago,

and we had just gone live with
an application at two sites,
and we hit a performance problem.

We couldn't buy the
hardware, new hardware,

because we didn't have
any capital for that.
So on the back of a company credit card,
we quickly spun up a couple of instances
with two people on AWS at the time.
What we managed to do on that environment,
was able to scale out that environment
at a fraction of the cost,
but be able to constantly test and scale
and run load testing on there
to try to troubleshoot and fix the issue.

We saw the value of how
to use that platform

without having to put
significant investment in.
So we had our platform established,
we had our teams trained,
and we needed to accelerate
how we moved more of our applications
into this new way of operating.
So we decided to partner with industries,
AWS Professional Services and Versent,
in this particular case.
AWS Professional Services

is a consulting arm of
Amazon Web Services.
We work together with our customers
to make sure that their cloud journey
is as smooth as possible.
AWS Professional Services and Versent

worked collaboratively
with the eHealth team

to successfully deliver
the mass migration project.

We were tasked and
challenged at the start

to really transform what we
were recommending to eHealth.
It would really take a replatform
and a transformational approach,
but not only just the technology,
the people taking an agile approach,

and really the tools as well
to take an automated approach
to the entire process,
rather than just taking what was existing
and placing that in AWS.
By partnering with our cloud providers,

we engaged with them through
their professional services arm
to come and embed within our product teams

and work with our new cloud
engineers to upskill them

on cloud technology,
ways of working, DevOps,

and we found it very beneficial
for our cloud engineers

to have the expertise of
world leaders in this space
working alongside them every day.
For example, we've migrated eight

of our largest clinical
applications to the AWS cloud space,
and we've been lucky enough to partner
with some of our application vendors

to be the first organisation,
either nationally or globally,

to rehost these applications
in the cloud space.

I can honestly say I
couldn't tell the difference
between an eHealth member of staff
or a Proserv member of staff.
And they essentially helped us as one
to move our platforms together.
Some of the main skills we picked up

as part of this engagement
was infrastructure as code,
DevOps, pipelines, code pipelines,
using Terraform to code services

and gaining familiarity with
the whole set of services
offered by AWS.

The benefits of learning
how to code infrastructure

has been that we can provision
services much quicker
on behalf of our customers,
and we can do so in a much more efficient,
repeatable manner.
This has proven invaluable for us

because of the time
savings, the stability,

and the time to actually
get services up and running.
A good example of this is
with our imaging repository application.

So this has a really
large storage footprint
of about 1.6 petabytes of data,

and it grows at around 25%
per year at the moment.
By leveraging AWS FSx for ONTAP,

we're able to drastically
reduce the amount of time

that it takes to provision new
storage for this application
to keep up with the growth rate.
It used to take a number of weeks on-prem

to go through the process of
configuring and installing

the hardware, let alone
the procurement process
that's behind that,

whereas in the cloud, it now
takes a matter of minutes.
In eHealth New South Wales,

we've had a customer who's
been really ambitious
about that move to cloud.
It's about finding the efficiencies

within those applications
of those architectures,

replatforming what they can
to gain those efficiencies,

and making the most of
what the cloud provides

in turn to provide that benefit
back to their clinicians
and their consumers,
which are patients in New South Wales.

It's very rare to be
able to have an opportunity
to work on a project of such scale.

In this work, we impacted
8 million citizens
and over 220 hospitals.

Versent has been really
proud over the last two years

to work alongside eHealth
and AWS Professional Services

to deliver such a
monumentous transformation,

but really what we've
seen is the growth within

eHealth's people to go
from a standing start,

not knowing the techniques
and tools within AWS cloud,
but now to become specialists themselves.
We definitely saw the benefits
of this partnership approach.
So, the eHealth staff,

we are SMEs in running the
clinical applications,

By partnering with AWS and bringing

to work alongside our teams
and upskill our teams,

we were able to get the best
of the technology aspect,

and this experience has shown
